Value: %{x}' ), row=i+1, col=1 ) # Add reference limit markers (Vertical lines) fig.add_trace( go.Scatter( y=m_data['server'], x=m_data['reference_limit'], mode='markers', marker=dict( symbol='line-ns-open', size=24, line=dict(width=4, color='red') ), name='Reference Limit', showlegend=(i == 0), hovertemplate='Limit: %{x}' ), row=i+1, col=1 ) # Highlight servers exceeding the limit exceeded = m_data[m_data['current_value'] > m_data['reference_limit']] if not exceeded.empty: fig.add_trace( go.Scatter( y=exceeded['server'], x=exceeded['current_value'] + 2, mode='text', text='⚠️', textposition='middle right', name='Limit Exceeded', showlegend=False ), row=i+1, col=1 ) # Layout adjustments for a clean, professional finish fig.update_layout( title='Server Performance Metrics vs. Capacity Limits', height=900, width=900, template='plotly_white', legend=dict(orientation="h", yanchor="bottom", y=1.02, xanchor="right", x=1), margin=dict(l=100, r=50, t=120, b=50) ) fig.update_xaxes(title_text="Metric Value") fig.update_yaxes(autorange="reversed") # Standard server A-D ordering fig.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('6apple_products.csv')

# Set aesthetic style
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))

# Create a scatter plot visualizing the relationship between Sale Price and Number of Ratings
# We use Star Rating for color and Discount Percentage for size to add dimensions
scatter = sns.scatterplot(
    data=df,
    x="Sale Price",
    y="Number Of Ratings",
    hue="Star Rating",
    size="Discount Percentage",
    sizes=(20, 400),
    palette="viridis",
    alpha=0.7
)

# Annotate a few key points (Highest rated and most expensive)
top_rated = df.loc[df['Number Of Ratings'].idxmax()]
plt.annotate(
    top_rated['Product Name'].split('(')[0],
    xy=(top_rated['Sale Price'], top_rated['Number Of Ratings']),
    xytext=(top_rated['Sale Price']+5000, top_rated['Number Of Ratings']+2000),
    arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle='->', color='black')
)

# Customizing the labels and title
plt.title('Apple Products: Sale Price vs. Popularity (Ratings)', fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')

plt.ylabel('Number of Ratings', fontsize=12)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set the visual style
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")

# Load the dataset
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('6apple_products.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # This block allows the script to be portable if the file is missing locally
    import io
    data = """Product Name,Sale Price,Number Of Ratings,Star Rating
    APPLE iPhone 8 Plus (Gold, 64 GB),49900,3431,4.6
    Apple iPhone XR ((PRODUCT)RED, 128 GB),41999,79512,4.6
    Apple iPhone XR (Black, 64 GB),39999,79512,4.6
    Apple iPhone SE (White, 256 GB),44999,95909,4.5
    APPLE iPhone 12 Pro (Silver, 512 GB),140900,542,4.5
    APPLE iPhone 11 (White, 128 GB),54999,43707,4.6
    APPLE iPhone SE (White, 64 GB),29999,95807,4.5
    APPLE iPhone SE (Black, 128 GB),34999,95909,4.5
    APPLE iPhone 11 (Black, 64 GB),46999,43470,4.6"""
    df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(data))

# Select top 10 products by Number of Ratings for a clean visualization
top_products = df.nlargest(10, 'Number Of Ratings').sort_values('Number Of Ratings')

# Initialize the matplotlib figure
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))

# Create a horizontal bar chart
# We use Star Rating for the color hue to provide a third dimension of data
norm = plt.Normalize(top_products['Star Rating'].min(), top_products['Star Rating'].max())
sm = plt.cm.ScalarMappable(cmap="RdYlGn", norm=norm)
colors = plt.cm.RdYlGn(norm(top_products['Star Rating']))

bars = plt.barh(top_products['Product Name'], 
                top_products['Number Of Ratings'], 
                color=colors, 
                edgecolor='black',
                alpha=0.8)

# Add a colorbar to explain the Star Rating
cbar = plt.colorbar(sm, aspect=30)
cbar.set_label('Star Rating', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')

# Formatting labels and title
plt.title('Popularity vs. Rating: Top 10 Most Rated Apple Products', fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
plt.xlabel('Number Of Ratings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
plt.ylabel('Product Name', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')

# Add data labels to the end of each bar
for bar in bars:
    width = bar.get_width()
    plt.text(width + (max(top_products['Number Of Ratings']) * 0.01), 
             bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2, 
             f'{int(width):,}', 
             va='center', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.dates as mdates

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('6beer.csv')

# Convert 'Month' to datetime objects for accurate time-series plotting
df['Month'] = pd.to_datetime(df['Month'])

# Calculate a 12-month rolling average to highlight the underlying trend
df['Trend'] = df['Monthly beer production'].rolling(window=12, center=True).mean()

# Set up the visual style
plt.style.use('seaborn-v0_8-muted')
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 6))

# Plot the raw monthly data
ax.plot(df['Month'], df['Monthly beer production'], 
        color='#3498db', alpha=0.6, linewidth=1.5, label='Monthly Production')

# Plot the trend line
ax.plot(df['Month'], df['Trend'], 
        color='#e74c3c', linewidth=2.5, label='12-Month Moving Average')

# Fill the area between the trend and raw data to emphasize seasonality
ax.fill_between(df['Month'], df['Trend'], df['Monthly beer production'], 
                color='#3498db', alpha=0.1)

# Formatting axes
ax.set_title('Trends in Monthly Beer Production (1956-1964)', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax.set_ylabel('Production Volume', fontsize=11)
ax.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=11)

# Improve x-axis date ticks
ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(mdates.YearLocator())
ax.xaxis.set_major_formatter(mdates.DateFormatter('%Y'))

# Adding grid and legend
ax.grid(True, linestyle='--', alpha=0.5)
ax.legend(frameon=True, facecolor='white', loc='upper left')

# Remove top and right spines for a cleaner look
ax.spines['top'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['right'].set_visible(False)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.dates as mdates
import seaborn as sns

# Set professional visualization style
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
plt.rcParams['font.family'] = 'sans-serif'

# Load the dataset
# Assuming '6beer.csv' is in the current directory
df = pd.read_csv('6beer.csv')
df['Month'] = pd.to_datetime(df['Month'])

# Initialize the figure
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 7), dpi=100)

# Calculate a 12-month rolling average to highlight the underlying trend
df['Trend'] = df['Monthly beer production'].rolling(window=12, center=True).mean()

# Plot the raw seasonal data
sns.lineplot(
    data=df, 
    x='Month', 
    y='Monthly beer production', 
    color='#34495e', 
    alpha=0.4, 
    linewidth=1.5, 
    label='Monthly Production',
    ax=ax
)

# Plot the trend line (expert addition to show growth)
sns.lineplot(
    data=df, 
    x='Month', 
    y='Trend', 
    color='#e74c3c', 
    linewidth=3, 
    label='12-Month Moving Average (Trend)',
    ax=ax
)

# Formatting the X-Axis to show years clearly
ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(mdates.YearLocator())
ax.xaxis.set_major_formatter(mdates.DateFormatter('%Y'))

# Refine Labels and Title
ax.set_title('Monthly Beer Production Analysis (1956 - 1964)', fontsize=20, fontweight='bold', pad=20, loc='left')
ax.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax.set_ylabel('Production Volume', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')

# Aesthetic refinements
sns.despine(left=True, bottom=True)
ax.legend(frameon=False, loc='upper left', fontsize=11)
plt.grid(axis='x', visible=False)

# Highlight seasonal peaks/troughs via layout
plt.tight_layout()

# Save or show
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set visual style
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
plt.rcParams['font.family'] = 'sans-serif'

# Load the data
df = pd.read_csv('6big mac.csv')

# Filter for the year 2001 to get a representative cross-section
df_2001 = df[df['date'] == '2001-04-01'].copy()
df_2001 = df_2001.sort_values('dollar_price', ascending=True)

# Create the figure
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 10))

# Create color map to highlight the United States as the benchmark
benchmark_price = df_2001[df_2001['iso_a3'] == 'USA']['dollar_price'].iloc[0]
colors = ['#d1d1d1' if x != 'USA' else '#e74c3c' for x in df_2001['iso_a3']]

# Horizontal bar plot
bars = ax.barh(df_2001['name'], df_2001['dollar_price'], color=colors, edgecolor='black', linewidth=0.5)

# Add a vertical line for the US Price
ax.axvline(benchmark_price, color='#e74c3c', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, label=f'US Price Benchmark (${benchmark_price:.2f})')

# Annotate values on bars
for bar in bars:
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax.text(width + 0.05, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2, 
            f'${width:.2f}', va='center', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Styling and Labels
ax.set_title('The Big Mac Index: Relative Prices in USD (April 2001)', loc='left', fontsize=18, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax.set_xlabel('Price converted to USD', fontsize=12, labelpad=10)
ax.set_ylabel('')
ax.xaxis.set_ticks_position('top')
ax.xaxis.set_label_position('top')

# Remove unnecessary spines
sns.despine(left=True, bottom=True)

plt.legend(loc='lower right', frameon=True, facecolor='white')
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('7bloodtype.csv')

# Preprocessing: Sort by population and take the top 15 countries for clarity
# Dropping rows with missing values (e.g., Egypt) to ensure the stack reaches 100%
top_countries = df.dropna().sort_values('Population', ascending=False).head(15)

# List of blood types in a logical stacking order
blood_types = ['O+', 'A+', 'B+', 'AB+', 'O-', 'A-', 'B-', 'AB-']

# Define a professional color palette
# Reds/Oranges for Positive types, Blues/Purples for Negative types
colors = ['#d73027', '#f46d43', '#fdae61', '#fee090', '#e0f3f8', '#abd9e9', '#74add1', '#4575b4']

# Initialize the plot
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 8))

# Create horizontal stacked bar chart
top_countries.set_index('Country')[blood_types].plot(
    kind='barh', 
    stacked=True, 
    ax=ax, 
    color=colors,
    width=0.8,
    edgecolor='white',
    linewidth=0.5
)

# Refine aesthetics
ax.set_title('Blood Type Distribution in the Top 15 Most Populous Countries', fontsize=16, pad=20, fontweight='bold')
ax.set_xlabel('Percentage of Population (%)', fontsize=12)
ax.set_ylabel('Country', fontsize=12)
ax.invert_yaxis()  # Put the largest population at the top
ax.grid(axis='x', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)

# Move legend outside the plot area
ax.legend(title='Blood Type', bbox_to_anchor=(1.02, 1), loc='upper left', borderaxespad=0.)

# Add data source note
plt.figtext(0.99, 0.01, 'Source: 7bloodtype.csv | Chart sorted by Population Size', 
            horizontalalignment='right', fontsize=8, alpha=0.6)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

def generate_blood_type_visualization():
    # Load the dataset
    try:
        df = pd.read_csv('7bloodtype.csv')
    except FileNotFoundError:
        return "Error: 7bloodtype.csv not found."

    # Data Cleaning: Remove rows with missing blood type values (e.g., Egypt)
    blood_type_cols = ['O+', 'A+', 'B+', 'AB+', 'O-', 'A-', 'B-', 'AB-']
    df = df.dropna(subset=blood_type_cols)

    # Select the Top 20 most populous countries for a clear, readable visualization
    df_plot = df.nlargest(20, 'Population').copy()
    
    # Set up the plotting style
    sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 10))

    # Define a color palette that distinguishes Positive and Negative Rh factors
    # Warm colors for Positive, Cool colors for Negative
    colors = [
        '#2ecc71', '#3498db', '#9b59b6', '#f1c40f', # O+, A+, B+, AB+
        '#27ae60', '#2980b9', '#8e44ad', '#f39c12'  # O-, A-, B-, AB- (darker variants)
    ]

    # Plot stacked horizontal bar chart
    df_plot.set_index('Country')[blood_type_cols].plot(
        kind='barh', 
        stacked=True, 
        ax=ax, 
        color=colors,
        width=0.8
    )

    # Customizing the chart aesthetics
    ax.set_title('Blood Type Distribution in the Top 20 Most Populous Countries', fontsize=18, pad=20, fontweight='bold')
    ax.set_xlabel('Percentage (%)', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
    ax.set_ylabel('Country', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
    ax.invert_yaxis()  # Put the most populous country at the top
    
    # Move legend outside the plot
    ax.legend(title='Blood Type', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left', frameon=True)

    # Add data labels for the largest segments (O+ and A+) for quick insight
    for i, (index, row) in enumerate(df_plot.iterrows()):
        cumulative = 0
        # Label O+ (usually the largest)
        val = row['O+']
        if val > 5:
            ax.text(val/2, i, f'{val:.1f}%', va='center', ha='center', color='white', fontweight='bold', fontsize=9)
        
        # Label A+ (usually the second largest)
        cumulative += val
        val_a = row['A+']
        if val_a > 10:
            ax.text(cumulative + val_a/2, i, f'{val_a:.1f}%', va='center', ha='center', color='white', fontweight='bold', fontsize=9)

    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    generate_blood_type_visualization()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set the visual style for a professional "expert" look
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid", palette="muted")
plt.rcParams['font.family'] = 'sans-serif'

def generate_nutrition_chart(file_path):
    # Load the dataset
    try:
        df = pd.read_csv(file_path)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print(f"Error: {file_path} not found.")
        return

    # Prepare data: Focus on Macronutrient composition (Fat, Protein, Carbs) per food item
    # We sort by Caloric Value to provide a logical hierarchy to the chart
    df_plot = df.sort_values('Caloric Value', ascending=True)
    
    # Define the macronutrients for the stacked bar
    macros = ['Fat', 'Protein', 'Carbohydrates']
    colors = ['#ff9999', '#66b3ff', '#99ff99']

    # Create the figure
    fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 10))

    # Plotting horizontal stacked bars for Macronutrients
    df_plot.plot(
        x='food', 
        y=macros, 
        kind='barh', 
        stacked=True, 
        ax=ax1, 
        color=colors,
        width=0.8,
        alpha=0.85
    )

    # Add a secondary axis to plot 'Nutrition Density' as a trend line/points
    ax2 = ax1.twiny()
    ax2.plot(
        df_plot['Nutrition Density'], 
        range(len(df_plot)), 
        color='#4B0082', 
        marker='o', 
        linestyle='--', 
        linewidth=1, 
        label='Nutrition Density'
    )

    # Formatting and Styling
    ax1.set_title('Nutritional Profile of Cheeses: Macronutrient Composition vs. Density Score', 
                  fontsize=18, fontweight='bold', pad=30, loc='left')
    
    ax1.set_xlabel('Grams per Serving (Stacked: Fat, Protein, Carbs)', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
    ax2.set_xlabel('Nutrition Density Score Index', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold', color='#4B0082')
    ax1.set_ylabel('Cheese Variety', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')

    # Legend handling
    lines, labels = ax1.get_legend_handles_labels()
    lines2, labels2 = ax2.get_legend_handles_labels()
    ax1.legend(lines + lines2, labels + labels2, loc='lower right', frameon=True, shadow=True)

    # Refine layout
    plt.tight_layout()
    
    # Save or Show
    plt.show()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    generate_nutrition_chart('7food.csv')

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set visual style
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")

# Load the dataset
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('7livingcost.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # Fallback for demonstration if file isn't found locally
    import io
    print("CSV file not found. Please ensure '7livingcost.csv' is in the directory.")
    exit()

# List of cost components to visualize
cost_components = [
    'housing_cost', 'food_cost', 'transportation_cost', 
    'healthcare_cost', 'other_necessities_cost', 'childcare_cost', 'taxes'
]

# Filtering for a specific family type (1 parent, 2 children) to compare across counties
# This provides a more consistent "apples-to-apples" regional comparison
filtered_df = df[df['family_member_count'] == '1p2c'].copy()

# Sorting by total cost for a better visual narrative
filtered_df = filtered_df.sort_values('total_cost', ascending=False)

# Creating the stacked bar chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 8))

# We use the bottom parameter in bar to create the stack manually for precision
bottoms = [0] * len(filtered_df)
colors = sns.color_palette("Spectral", len(cost_components))

for i, component in enumerate(cost_components):
    ax.bar(
        filtered_df['county'], 
        filtered_df[component], 
        bottom=bottoms, 
        label=component.replace('_', ' ').title(),
        color=colors[i],
        edgecolor='white',
        linewidth=0.5
    )
    bottoms = [b + v for b, v in zip(bottoms, filtered_df[component])]

# Adding the Median Family Income as a reference line (scatter points)
ax.scatter(
    filtered_df['county'], 
    filtered_df['median_family_income'], 
    color='black', 
    label='Median Family Income', 
    zorder=5, 
    marker='D', 
    s=50
)

# Customizing the axes and labels
ax.set_title('Annual Cost of Living vs. Median Income (Family Type: 1 Parent, 2 Children)', fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax.set_ylabel('Annual Cost / Income ($)', fontsize=12)
ax.set_xlabel('County (Alabama)', fontsize=12)

# Formatting Y-axis to display currency
ax.yaxis.set_major_formatter(plt.FuncFormatter(lambda x, p: f'${int(x):,}'))

# Rotating county names for readability
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')

# Placing the legend outside the plot
ax.legend(title='Cost Categories', bbox_to_anchor=(1.02, 1), loc='upper left', frameon=False)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set professional visualization style
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
plt.rcParams["font.family"] = "sans-serif"

def generate_living_cost_chart(file_path):
    # Load the dataset
    try:
        df = pd.read_csv(file_path)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        return "Error: CSV file not found."

    # Define the cost components for the stacked bar chart
    cost_components = [
        'housing_cost', 'food_cost', 'transportation_cost', 
        'healthcare_cost', 'other_necessities_cost', 
        'childcare_cost', 'taxes'
    ]
    
    # Human-readable labels for the legend
    labels = [c.replace('_', ' ').title() for c in cost_components]

    # Aggregate data by family size to show average costs per configuration
    # Note: family_member_count format is '1p0c' (1 parent, 0 children), etc.
    df_avg = df.groupby('family_member_count')[cost_components].mean()

    # Sort the index logically: 1-parent families first, then 2-parent families, both by child count
    def sort_key(idx):
        p = int(idx[0])
        c = int(idx[2])
        return (p, c)
    
    df_avg = df_avg.reindex(sorted(df_avg.index, key=sort_key))

    # Create the figure
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 8))

    # Plot stacked bars
    df_avg.plot(kind='bar', stacked=True, ax=ax, color=sns.color_palette("Spectral", len(cost_components)))

    # Aesthetic formatting
    plt.title('Composition of Annual Living Costs by Family Type in Alabama', fontsize=18, pad=20, fontweight='bold')
    plt.xlabel('Family Configuration (p = parent, c = child)', fontsize=12, labelpad=10)
    plt.ylabel('Average Annual Cost ($)', fontsize=12, labelpad=10)
    plt.xticks(rotation=0, fontsize=11)
    
    # Format Y-axis with dollar signs and commas
    ax.yaxis.set_major_formatter(plt.FuncFormatter(lambda x, loc: f"${x:,.0f}"))

    # Place legend outside the chart for clarity
    plt.legend(labels, title='Cost Categories', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left', frameon=True)

    # Add data labels for the total cost on top of each bar
    totals = df_avg.sum(axis=1)
    for i, total in enumerate(totals):
        ax.text(i, total + 1000, f'${total/1000:.1f}k', ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold', color='#333333')

    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    generate_living_cost_chart('7livingcost.csv')

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set professional visualization style
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
plt.rcParams["font.family"] = "sans-serif"

def generate_pokemon_chart(file_path):
    # Load the dataset
    try:
        df = pd.read_csv(file_path)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print(f"Error: {file_path} not found.")
        return

    # Sort data by Total stats for better visual ranking
    df_sorted = df.sort_values("Total", ascending=False)

    # Initialize the matplotlib figure
    f, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 8))

    # Create a color palette based on the 'Total' values
    norm = plt.Normalize(df_sorted['Total'].min(), df_sorted['Total'].max())
    sm = plt.cm.ScalarMappable(cmap="viridis_r", norm=norm)
    sm.set_array([])

    # Plotting the horizontal bar chart
    barplot = sns.barplot(
        data=df_sorted,
        x="Total",
        y="Name",
        hue="Total",
        palette="viridis_r",
        legend=False,
        edgecolor=".2"
    )

    # Add labels to the ends of the bars for precision
    for i, p in enumerate(barplot.patches):
        width = p.get_width()
        ax.text(width + 5, p.get_y() + p.get_height()/2 + 0.1, 
                f'{int(width)}', ha="left", va="center", 
                fontsize=10, fontweight='bold', color='#333333')

    # Aesthetic refinements
    ax.set_title("Base Stat Totals of Selected Pokemon", fontsize=18, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
    ax.set_xlabel("Total Points (HP + Atk + Def + Sp.Atk + Sp.Def + Speed)", fontsize=12, labelpad=10)
    ax.set_ylabel("Pokemon Name", fontsize=12)
    
    # Remove top and right spines
    sns.despine(left=True, bottom=True)
    
    # Adjust layout and display
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    generate_pokemon_chart('8Pokemon.csv')

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load data and handle non-numeric 'Na' values
df = pd.read_csv('9Income.csv')

# Convert weekly earnings columns to numeric, forcing 'Na' to NaN
numeric_cols = ['M_weekly', 'F_weekly']
for col in numeric_cols:
    df[col] = pd.to_numeric(df[col], errors='coerce')

# Filter to specific management roles and remove rows with missing data for comparison
# We exclude the top-level aggregates "ALL OCCUPATIONS" and "MANAGEMENT"
df_plot = df.dropna(subset=['M_weekly', 'F_weekly'])
df_plot = df_plot[~df_plot['Occupation'].isin(['ALL OCCUPATIONS', 'MANAGEMENT'])]

# Sort by Male earnings to provide better visual hierarchy
df_plot = df_plot.sort_values('M_weekly', ascending=False)

# Prepare data for plotting (long format)
df_melted = df_plot.melt(
    id_vars='Occupation', 
    value_vars=['M_weekly', 'F_weekly'], 
    var_name='Gender', 
    value_name='Weekly_Earnings'
)
df_melted['Gender'] = df_melted['Gender'].map({'M_weekly': 'Male', 'F_weekly': 'Female'})

# Visualization setup
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))

# Create horizontal grouped bar chart
palette = {"Male": "#3498db", "Female": "#e74c3c"}
ax = sns.barplot(
    data=df_melted, 
    y='Occupation', 
    x='Weekly_Earnings', 
    hue='Gender', 
    palette=palette
)

# Customizing the chart aesthetics
plt.title('Median Weekly Earnings by Gender in Management Occupations', fontsize=16, pad=20)
plt.xlabel('Median Weekly Earnings ($)', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('', fontsize=12)
plt.legend(title='Gender', loc='lower right')

# Add data labels to the end of each bar
for p in ax.patches:
    width = p.get_width()
    if width > 0:
        ax.annotate(f'${int(width)}', 
                    (width, p.get_y() + p.get_height() / 2.), 
                    ha='left', va='center', 
                    xytext=(5, 0), 
                    textcoords='offset points',
                    fontsize=10)

plt.tight_layout()
sns.despine(left=True, bottom=True)
plt.show()

import numpy as np

# Load the dataset
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('9Income.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # This block allows the script to be portable if the file is missing by using provided data
    from io import StringIO
    csv_data = """Occupation,All_workers,All_weekly,M_workers,M_weekly,F_workers,F_weekly
ALL OCCUPATIONS,109080,809,60746,895,48334,726
MANAGEMENT,12480,1351,7332,1486,5147,1139
Chief executives,1046,2041,763,2251,283,1836
General and operations managers,823,1260,621,1347,202,1002
Legislators,8,Na,5,Na,4,Na
Advertising and promotions managers,55,1050,29,Na,26,Na
Marketing and sales managers,948,1462,570,1603,378,1258
Public relations and fundraising managers,59,1557,24,Na,35,Na
Administrative services managers,170,1191,96,1451,73,981
Computer and information systems managers,636,1728,466,1817,169,1563
Financial managers,1124,1408,551,1732,573,1130
Compensation and benefits managers,23,Na,7,Na,16,Na
Human resources managers,254,1365,68,1495,186,1274
Training and development managers,37,Na,17,Na,20,Na
Industrial production managers,267,1485,221,1528,45,Na
Purchasing managers,193,1348,109,1404,84,1226
Transportation, storage, and distribution managers,276,966,224,1006,52,749
Farmers, ranchers, and other agricultural managers,129,769,106,847,23,Na
Construction managers,471,1329,429,1357,42,Na
Education administrators,778,1423,282,1585,496,1252
Architectural and engineering managers,110,1899,101,1892,10,Na
Food service managers,763,742,389,820,374,680"""
    df = pd.read_csv(StringIO(csv_data))

# Data Cleaning
# Convert weekly earnings to numeric, coercing 'Na' to NaN
cols_to_clean = ['All_weekly', 'M_weekly', 'F_weekly']
for col in cols_to_clean:
    df[col] = pd.to_numeric(df[col], errors='coerce')

# Filter for specific management roles (excluding the top aggregate rows)
# and only include rows where both Male and Female data are available for comparison
comparison_df = df.iloc[2:].dropna(subset=['M_weekly', 'F_weekly']).copy()
comparison_df = comparison_df.sort_values('All_weekly', ascending=True)

# Set visual style
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 8))

# Define bar positions
y = np.arange(len(comparison_df))
height = 0.35

# Create horizontal bars
rects1 = ax.barh(y + height/2, comparison_df['M_weekly'], height, label='Male', color='#3498db', edgecolor='white')
rects2 = ax.barh(y - height/2, comparison_df['F_weekly'], height, label='Female', color='#e74c3c', edgecolor='white')

# Aesthetics
ax.set_xlabel('Median Weekly Earnings ($)', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold', labelpad=15)
ax.set_title('Gender Pay Gap in Management Occupations\n(Median Weekly Earnings Comparison)', 
             fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax.set_yticks(y)
ax.set_yticklabels(comparison_df['Occupation'], fontsize=10)
ax.legend(frameon=True, loc='lower right', fontsize=11)

# Adding value labels to the end of bars for precision
def autolabel(rects):
    for rect in rects:
        width = rect.get_width()
        ax.annotate(f'${int(width)}',
                    xy=(width, rect.get_y() + rect.get_height() / 2),
                    xytext=(3, 0),  # 3 points horizontal offset
                    textcoords="offset points",
                    ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, color='#444444')

autolabel(rects1)
autolabel(rects2)

# Despine and tighten layout
sns.despine(left=True, bottom=True)
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('10VG.csv')

# Set aesthetic style for high-level data interpretation
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
plt.figure(figsize=(14, 10))

# Create a multi-dimensional scatter plot to facilitate "reading beyond" the data
# X/Y axes compare the two largest markets to identify regional dominance
# Size represents the Global Sales impact
# Color identifies Genre clusters
scatter = sns.scatterplot(
    data=df,
    x='NA_Sales',
    y='EU_Sales',
    hue='Genre',
    size='Global_Sales',
    sizes=(100, 1500),
    alpha=0.7,
    palette='Spectral'
)

# Annotate points to allow for specific outlier analysis (e.g., Duck Hunt's NA-skew)
for i in range(df.shape[0]):
    plt.text(
        df.NA_Sales[i] + 0.5, 
        df.EU_Sales[i], 
        df.Name[i], 
        fontsize=9, 
        alpha=0.8, 
        va='center'
    )

# Add a parity line (NA = EU) to help visualize market bias
# Games above this line performed better in Europe relative to North America
max_limit = max(df['NA_Sales'].max(), df['EU_Sales'].max())
plt.plot([0, max_limit], [0, max_limit], color='gray', linestyle='--', alpha=0.5)
plt.text(30, 31, "EU Market Bias", color='gray', rotation=38)
plt.text(32, 28, "NA Market Bias", color='gray', rotation=38)

# Title and labels designed for synthesis of market trends
plt.title('Regional Market Dynamics: NA vs EU Sales Performance\n(Bubble Size = Global Sales | Line = Market Parity)', fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel('North America Sales (Millions)', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Europe Sales (Millions)', fontsize=12)

# Adjust legend to not overlap data
plt.legend(bbox_to_anchor=(1.02, 1), loc='upper left', title="Genre & Scale")

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Load the dataset
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('11company_revenue.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # Fallback for demonstration if file is not in local directory
    from io import StringIO
    data = """Quarter,Company_A,Company_B,Company_C
Q1_2022,150000,120000,95000
Q2_2022,165000,128000,102000
Q3_2022,172000,135000,108000
Q4_2022,185000,145000,115000
Q1_2023,195000,152000,125000
Q2_2023,210000,165000,138000
Q3_2023,225000,178000,145000
Q4_2023,240000,190000,158000
Q1_2024,258000,205000,172000
Q2_2024,275000,220000,185000
Q3_2024,290000,235000,198000
Q4_2024,310000,250000,210000"""
    df = pd.read_csv(StringIO(data))

# Preparation for 'Read Beyond' analysis (Forecasting and Trend Inference)
x_numeric = np.arange(len(df))
forecast_steps = 4
x_forecast = np.arange(len(df) + forecast_steps)
future_labels = list(df['Quarter']) + ['Q1_2025', 'Q2_2025', 'Q3_2025', 'Q4_2025']

plt.figure(figsize=(14, 8))
colors = ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c']
companies = ['Company_A', 'Company_B', 'Company_C']

for i, company in enumerate(companies):
    # Plot historical data
    plt.plot(df['Quarter'], df[company], marker='o', label=f'{company} (Actual)', color=colors[i], linewidth=2.5)
    
    # Calculate Linear Regression for "Read Beyond" inference
    slope, intercept = np.polyfit(x_numeric, df[company], 1)
    trendline = slope * x_forecast + intercept
    
    # Plot trend/forecast
    plt.plot(future_labels, trendline, linestyle='--', color=colors[i], alpha=0.5, label=f'{company} Forecast')
    
    # Annotate growth rate
    total_growth = ((df[company].iloc[-1] - df[company].iloc[0]) / df[company].iloc[0]) * 100
    plt.text(len(df)-1, df[company].iloc[-1] + 5000, f'{total_growth:.1f}% Growth', color=colors[i], fontweight='bold')

plt.title('Revenue Momentum & 2025 Forecast: Comparative Analysis', fontsize=16, pad=20)
plt.ylabel('Revenue (USD)', fontsize=12)
plt.xlabel('Fiscal Period', fontsize=12)
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.grid(axis='y', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)
plt.axvspan(len(df)-1, len(future_labels)-1, color='gray', alpha=0.1, label='Projection Window')
plt.legend(loc='upper left', bbox_to_anchor=(1, 1))
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import io

# Load data
csv_data = """Week,Math_Score,Science_Score,English_Score
1,65,70,72
2,68,72,75
3,70,75,78
4,72,73,80
5,75,76,82
6,78,78,85
7,80,81,87
8,82,83,88
9,85,85,90
10,87,88,92
11,88,90,93
12,90,92,95"""

df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_data))

# Visualization settings
plt.style.use('ggplot')
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 8))
subjects = ['Math_Score', 'Science_Score', 'English_Score']
colors = ['#3498db', '#e67e22', '#2ecc71']
future_weeks = np.array(range(1, 16))

# Plotting with trend extrapolation (Read Beyond analysis)
for i, subject in enumerate(subjects):
    # Actual Data
    ax.plot(df['Week'], df[subject], marker='o', label=f'Actual {subject}', color=colors[i], linewidth=2)
    
    # Calculate Linear Regression for Trend Forecasting
    z = np.polyfit(df['Week'], df[subject], 1)
    p = np.poly1d(z)
    
    # Extrapolate beyond Week 12
    ax.plot(future_weeks[11:], p(future_weeks[11:]), linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, color=colors[i], 
            label=f'{subject} Projection (Growth Rate: {z[0]:.2f}/wk)')

# Formatting for Advanced Interpretation
ax.axvspan(12, 15, alpha=0.1, color='gray', label='Forecast Horizon')
ax.set_title('Longitudinal Academic Performance with Predictive Trend Analysis', fontsize=16, pad=20)
ax.set_xlabel('Week', fontsize=12)
ax.set_ylabel('Score %', fontsize=12)
ax.set_xticks(range(1, 16))
ax.set_ylim(60, 105)
ax.legend(loc='upper left', bbox_to_anchor=(1, 1), frameon=True)
ax.grid(True, which='both', linestyle='--', alpha=0.5)

# Highlighting the convergence point or notable trends for "Reading Beyond"
ax.annotate('Projected Mastery (100%)', xy=(14.5, 100), xytext=(10, 102),
            arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black', shrink=0.05, width=1, headwidth=5))

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Load the data provided in the prompt
csv_data = """age,population
<5,2704659
5-13,4499890
14-17,2159981
18-24,3853788
25-44,14106543
45-64,8819342
≥65,612463"""

df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_data))

# 'Read Beyond' Analysis: Calculate distribution density and cumulative impact
total_pop = df['population'].sum()
df['percentage'] = (df['population'] / total_pop) * 100
df['cumulative_percentage'] = df['percentage'].cumsum()

# Set up the visualization
fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 7))

# Plot Primary Data: Population counts per age group
bars = ax1.bar(df['age'], df['population'], color='#3498db', alpha=0.7, label='Group Population')
ax1.set_xlabel('Age Cohorts', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Population Count', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.ticklabel_format(style='plain', axis='y')
ax1.grid(axis='y', linestyle='--', alpha=0.6)

# Create Secondary Axis for 'Read Beyond' Inference: Cumulative Distribution
ax2 = ax1.twinx()
ax2.plot(df['age'], df['cumulative_percentage'], color='#e74c3c', marker='o', linewidth=2.5, label='Cumulative % of Total')
ax2.set_ylabel('Cumulative Percentage of Total Population (%)', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold', color='#e74c3c')
ax2.set_ylim(0, 105)

# Annotate the Mode (Reading Beyond: Identifying the core demographic bulge)
peak_val = df['population'].max()
peak_age = df.loc[df['population'].idxmax(), 'age']
peak_pct = df.loc[df['population'].idxmax(), 'percentage']

ax1.annotate(f'Demographic Peak:\n{peak_pct:.1f}% of population',
             xy=(peak_age, peak_val),
             xytext=(peak_age, peak_val + 1000000),
             ha='center',
             arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black', shrink=0.05, width=1, headwidth=8),
             fontsize=10, fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", fc="white", ec="#3498db", alpha=0.9))

# Final formatting
plt.title('Demographic Concentration Analysis: Population Bulge & Cumulative Distribution', fontsize=14, pad=20)
fig.legend(loc="upper left", bbox_to_anchor=(0.1, 0.85))
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('13Global YouTube Statistics.csv')

# Preprocessing: Filter out rows with missing critical values and normalize data for visualization
# We focus on the relationship between reach (subscribers) and monetization potential (earnings)
# categorized by niche to infer which categories yield higher efficiency.
df_filtered = df.dropna(subset=['category', 'highest_yearly_earnings', 'subscribers', 'video_views_for_the_last_30_days'])

# Setup for high-density information visualization (Curcio's 'Read Beyond' level)
plt.figure(figsize=(16, 9))
sns.set_context("talk")
sns.set_style("whitegrid")

# Create a Bubble Chart to analyze multi-dimensional relationships:
# 1. X-axis: Scale of audience (Subscribers)
# 2. Y-axis: Potential annual revenue (Highest Yearly Earnings)
# 3. Size: Velocity of growth/engagement (Video views for the last 30 days)
# 4. Color: Content Niche (Category)
scatter = sns.scatterplot(
    data=df_filtered,
    x='subscribers',
    y='highest_yearly_earnings',
    size='video_views_for_the_last_30_days',
    hue='category',
    sizes=(100, 3000),
    alpha=0.6,
    palette='Spectral',
    edgecolor='black'
)

# Statistical inference: Adding a regression trend line (overall) to see the baseline of subscriber-to-earning conversion
sns.regplot(
    data=df_filtered, 
    x='subscribers', 
    y='highest_yearly_earnings', 
    scatter=False, 
    color='gray', 
    line_kws={"ls": '--', "lw": 1.5},
    label='Global Trendline'
)

# Customizing the visual for analytical depth
plt.title('Monetization Efficiency & Engagement Velocity across Top 50 Global YouTube Channels', fontsize=20, pad=20)
plt.xlabel('Total Subscribers', fontsize=14)
plt.ylabel('Estimated Maximum Yearly Earnings (USD)', fontsize=14)

# Format axes to be more readable
def format_millions(x, pos):
    return f'{x/1e6:.0f}M'

plt.gca().xaxis.set_major_formatter(plt.FuncFormatter(format_millions))
plt.gca().yaxis.set_major_formatter(plt.FuncFormatter(format_millions))

# Handling the legend for multi-variable encoding
handles, labels = scatter.get_legend_handles_labels()
plt.legend(handles[0:len(df_filtered['category'].unique())+1], 
           labels[0:len(df_filtered['category'].unique())+1], 
           bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc=2, borderaxespad=0., title='Category')

# Annotation for outliers or significant clusters to aid "Read Beyond" inference
top_earner = df_filtered.loc[df_filtered['highest_yearly_earnings'].idxmax()]
plt.annotate(f"Highest Potential: {top_earner['Youtuber']}", 
             xy=(top_earner['subscribers'], top_earner['highest_yearly_earnings']),
             xytext=(top_earner['subscribers']-2e7, top_earner['highest_yearly_earnings']+5e6),
             arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle='->', color='black'))

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

            fontsize=10, fontweight='bold', color='#27ae60')

# Adding text description for literacy context
plt.figtext(0.5, 0.01, "Interpretation: The negative growth in ages 0-6 suggests a relative decline in births since 2020,\nwhile the growth in the 16-25 bracket reflects the progression of larger birth cohorts and net migration.", 
            ha="center", fontsize=10, bbox={"facecolor":"orange", "alpha":0.1, "pad":5})

plt.tight_layout(rect=[0, 0.05, 1, 1])
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Creating the CSV file locally for the script to run
data = {
    'Age_Group': ['0-19', '20-39', '40-59', '60+'],
    'Male_Customers': [120, 450, 300, 150],
    'Female_Customers': [140, 520, 310, 180]
}
df_init = pd.DataFrame(data)
df_init.to_csv('14_shop_customers_demographics.csv', index=False)

# Load the data
df = pd.read_csv('14_shop_customers_demographics.csv')

# Calculating total and percentage share for 'read beyond' level analysis
df['Total'] = df['Male_Customers'] + df['Female_Customers']
total_market = df['Total'].sum()
df['Market_Share'] = (df['Total'] / total_market) * 100

# Plotting
fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 7))

x = np.arange(len(df['Age_Group']))
width = 0.35

# Bar chart for gender distribution
bar1 = ax1.bar(x - width/2, df['Male_Customers'], width, label='Male', color='#5DADE2', edgecolor='white')
bar2 = ax1.bar(x + width/2, df['Female_Customers'], width, label='Female', color='#EC7063', edgecolor='white')

# Secondary axis for cumulative/trend analysis (Read Beyond)
ax2 = ax1.twinx()
line = ax2.plot(x, df['Market_Share'], color='#2C3E50', marker='o', linestyle='--', linewidth=2, label='Market Share %')

# Formatting labels and titles
ax1.set_xlabel('Age Group Segment', fontsize=12)
ax1.set_ylabel('Volume of Customers', fontsize=12)
ax2.set_ylabel('Percentage of Total Customer Base (%)', fontsize=12)
plt.title('Demographic Market Concentration & Gender Distribution\n(Targeting the 20-39 Core Growth Segment)', fontsize=14, pad=20)

ax1.set_xticks(x)
ax1.set_xticklabels(df['Age_Group'])

# Combined Legend
lines, labels = ax1.get_legend_handles_labels()
lines2, labels2 = ax2.get_legend_handles_labels()
ax1.legend(lines + lines2, labels + labels2, loc='upper left')

# Annotations for insights
for i, txt in enumerate(df['Market_Share']):
    ax2.annotate(f"{txt:.1f}%", (x[i], df['Market_Share'][i]), textcoords="offset points", xytext=(0,10), ha='center', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

plt.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Load data
csv_content = """City,Safety,Healthcare,Education,Environment,Economy,Traffic,Culture,Housing_Affordability
Seoul,85,90,95,70,85,60,90,40
Tokyo,90,92,90,75,88,65,85,50
New York,70,80,88,70,95,55,95,30
London,75,85,90,75,92,60,95,35
Paris,65,88,85,72,85,65,95,40
Berlin,80,85,80,85,82,75,90,55
Singapore,95,90,92,90,95,80,75,45
Sydney,85,88,85,92,88,70,80,40"""

# Attempting to read from file as requested, with a fallback to provided string data
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('15_city_quality_of_life.csv', index_col='City')
except FileNotFoundError:
    df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_content), index_col='City')

# For 'Read Beyond' level analysis, a Hierarchical Clustering Heatmap (Clustermap) is used.
# This visualization synthesizes multidimensional data to identify latent patterns, 
# clustering cities with similar socio-economic profiles and identifying correlations 
# between disparate metrics (e.g., the inverse relationship between Economy and Affordability).
sns.set_theme(style="white")
g = sns.clustermap(
    df, 
    cmap="RdYlGn", 
    standard_scale=1, 
    annot=True, 
    fmt=".2f",
    figsize=(12, 10),
    cbar_pos=(0.02, 0.8, 0.03, 0.15),
    dendrogram_ratio=(0.15, 0.15),
    linewidths=.5
)

# Refine labels and titles for synthesis
g.fig.suptitle('Comparative Urban Archetypes: Hierarchical Clustering of Quality of Life Indicators', 
               fontsize=16, fontweight='bold', y=1.02)
g.ax_heatmap.set_xlabel('Quality of Life Metrics (Standardized)', fontsize=12)
g.ax_heatmap.set_ylabel('City Profiles', fontsize=12)

plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Load the data
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('15_rpg_character_stats.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # Creating local dataframe based on provided metadata for script functionality
    data = {
        'Character_Class': ['Warrior', 'Mage', 'Rogue'],
        'Strength': [95, 30, 60],
        'Agility': [40, 50, 95],
        'Intelligence': [20, 95, 70],
        'Defense': [85, 30, 40],
        'Stamina': [90, 40, 60]
    }
    df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Extract attributes and classes
categories = ['Strength', 'Agility', 'Intelligence', 'Defense', 'Stamina']
N = len(categories)

# Calculate angles for the radar chart
angles = [n / float(N) * 2 * np.pi for n in range(N)]
angles += angles[:1] # Close the circular plot

# Initialize the spider plot
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 8), subplot_kw=dict(polar=True))

# Color palette for archetypes
colors = {'Warrior': '#d62728', 'Mage': '#1f77b4', 'Rogue': '#2ca02c'}

# Plot each character class to allow for "reading beyond" the data 
# (e.g., identifying specialization trade-offs and role archetypes)
for i, row in df.iterrows():
    values = row[categories].values.flatten().tolist()
    values += values[:1] # Close the circular plot
    
    char_class = row['Character_Class']
    ax.plot(angles, values, linewidth=2, linestyle='solid', label=char_class, color=colors.get(char_class))
    ax.fill(angles, values, color=colors.get(char_class), alpha=0.15)

# Fix axis to display categories
plt.xticks(angles[:-1], categories, color='grey', size=12)

# Set radial limits
ax.set_rlabel_position(0)
plt.yticks([25, 50, 75, 100], ["25", "50", "75", "100"], color="grey", size=8)
plt.ylim(0, 100)

# Add title and legend
plt.title('RPG Character Archetype Comparison: Multi-Dimensional Stat Distribution', 
          size=16, color='black', y=1.1)
plt.legend(loc='upper right', bbox_to_anchor=(1.2, 1.1))

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from io import StringIO

# Creating the data from the provided CSV content
csv_data = """Smartphone_Model,Battery_Life,Camera_Quality,Performance,Display,Design,Value_for_Money
Phone A,8.5,9.0,8.0,9.0,7.5,6.0

Phone D,6.0,7.0,7.5,7.0,8.5,9.5
Phone E,9.5,8.0,9.0,8.5,7.0,7.5"""

df = pd.read_csv(StringIO(csv_data))

# Identifying categories and number of variables
categories = list(df.columns[1:])
N = len(categories)

# Calculating angles for the radar chart
angles = [n / float(N) * 2 * np.pi for n in range(N)]
angles += angles[:1]

# Initialize the spider plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 10))
ax = plt.subplot(111, polar=True)

# Helper function to plot each smartphone
for i, row in df.iterrows():
    values = row[categories].values.flatten().tolist()
    values += values[:1]
    ax.plot(angles, values, linewidth=2, linestyle='solid', label=row['Smartphone_Model'])

a,32

c,100

d,88

         linestyle='--', linewidth=1, label='Mean Value')

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Load the dataset
# Assuming '16us_census_edu.csv' exists in the working directory
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('16us_census_edu.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # Creating the dataframe if the file is not found for demonstration purposes
    data = {
        'Education': ['Less than 9th grade', '9th to 12 grade (no diploma)', 'High school graduate', 
                      'Some college, no degree', 'Associate degree', "Bachelor's degree", 
                      "Master's degree", 'Doctorate'],
        'Women': [21284, 22472, 29119, 35499, 38149, 54411, 69022, 90906],
        'Men': [34479, 36837, 46833, 52852, 55795, 84486, 99363, 151019]
    }
    df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Calculate the pay gap percentage to facilitate 'read beyond' analysis (identifying trends in disparity)
df['Gap_Percentage'] = ((df['Men'] - df['Women']) / df['Men']) * 100

# Set up the visualization
fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 7))
x = np.arange(len(df['Education']))
width = 0.35

# Plotting the median earnings
rects1 = ax1.bar(x - width/2, df['Women'], width, label='Women', color='#9b59b6', alpha=0.8)
rects2 = ax1.bar(x + width/2, df['Men'], width, label='Men', color='#34495e', alpha=0.8)

# Adding labels and titles
ax1.set_xlabel('Highest Educational Attainment')
ax1.set_ylabel('Median Annual Earnings ($)')
ax1.set_title('US Census: Education vs. Median Earnings by Gender\nAnalysis of the Growing Income Gap at Higher Education Levels', fontsize=14)
ax1.set_xticks(x)
ax1.set_xticklabels(df['Education'], rotation=30, ha='right')
ax1.legend(loc='upper left')

# Secondary axis to plot the percentage gap (Read Beyond: connecting education level to disparity magnitude)
ax2 = ax1.twinx()
ax2.plot(x, df['Gap_Percentage'], color='#e74c3c', marker='o', linewidth=2, label='Income Gap %')
ax2.set_ylabel('Gender Income Gap (%)', color='#e74c3c')
ax2.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor='#e74c3c')
ax2.set_ylim(0, 50)
ax2.legend(loc='upper right')

# Grid and layout
ax1.yaxis.grid(True, linestyle='--', alpha=0.6)
plt.tight_layout()

# Save or show
plt.show()

from io import StringIO

csv_data = """flno,origin,destination,distance,departure_date,arrival_date,price,aid
99,Los Angeles,Washington D.C.,2308,2005-04-12 09:30:00,2005-04-12 09:40:00,235.98,1
13,Los Angeles,Chicago,1749,2005-04-12 08:45:00,2005-04-12 08:45:00,220.98,3
346,Los Angeles,Dallas,1251,2005-04-12 11:50:00,2005-04-12 07:05:00,182.00,2
387,Los Angeles,Boston,2606,2005-04-12 07:03:00,2005-04-12 05:03:00,261.56,6
7,Los Angeles,Sydney,7487,2005-04-12 05:30:00,2005-04-12 11:10:00,278.56,3
2,Los Angeles,Tokyo,5478,2005-04-12 06:30:00,2005-04-12 03:55:00,780.99,9
33,Los Angeles,Honolulu,2551,2005-04-12 09:15:00,2005-04-12 11:15:00,375.23,7
34,Los Angeles,Honolulu,2551,2005-04-12 12:45:00,2005-04-12 03:18:00,425.98,5
76,Chicago,Los Angeles,1749,2005-04-12 08:32:00,2005-04-12 10:03:00,220.98,9
68,Chicago,New York,802,2005-04-12 09:00:00,2005-04-12 12:02:00,202.45,10"""

df = pd.read_csv(StringIO(csv_data))

# Analytical Setup: Evaluating Value (Price per Unit of Distance)
# This addresses 'Read Beyond' by exploring the efficiency/cost relationship
df['price_per_mile'] = df['price'] / df['distance']

plt.figure(figsize=(12, 7))
sns.set_style("whitegrid")

# Create a scatter plot with a regression line to identify trends and outliers
plot = sns.regplot(data=df, x='distance', y='price', 
                   scatter_kws={'s': 100, 'alpha': 0.6}, 
                   line_kws={'color': 'red', 'linestyle': '--'})

# Annotate points to provide context for 'Reading Beyond' the raw numbers
for i in range(df.shape[0]):
    plt.text(df.distance[i]+100, df.price[i], 
             f"{df.destination[i]} (${df.price_per_mile[i]:.2f}/mi)", 
             fontsize=9, verticalalignment='center')

plt.title('Correlation Analysis: Flight Distance vs. Ticket Price\n(Labels indicate Destination and Price per Mile)', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Distance (miles)', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Price (USD)', fontsize=12)
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Data provided for 17voter_2Voting_record.csv
csv_data = """stuid,registration_date,election_cycle,president_vote,vice_president_vote,secretary_vote,treasurer_vote,class_president_vote,class_senator_vote
1001,2015-08-30,Spring,1004,1007,1010,1035,1001,1028
1002,2014-08-30,Spring,1014,1007,1020,1025,1021,1028
1003,2013-08-30,Spring,1004,1017,1030,1035,1031,1028
1004,2013-08-30,Spring,1024,1017,1020,1035,1011,1028
1005,2012-08-30,Spring,1024,1017,1010,1035,1021,1028
1001,2015-08-30,Fall,1004,1007,1010,1035,1021,1028
1002,2014-08-30,Fall,1004,1007,1020,1035,1021,1028
1003,2013-08-30,Fall,1004,1017,1020,1035,1031,1028
1004,2013-08-30,Fall,1024,1017,1020,1035,1011,1018
1005,2012-08-30,Fall,1024,1017,1010,1035,1021,1028"""

# Read the data into a DataFrame
df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_data))

# Analyzing 'Read Beyond' relationships: 
# Synthesizing how presidential candidate support shifts between election cycles.
# This allows inference on candidate momentum and voter consistency.
president_trends = df.groupby(['election_cycle', 'president_vote']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Create a visualization that compares the vote distribution shifts
ax = president_trends.plot(kind='bar', 
                           figsize=(11, 7), 
                           color=['#4E79A7', '#F28E2B', '#E15759'],
                           edgecolor='black')

# Enhancing metadata for inferential analysis
plt.title('Presidential Candidate Performance Shift: Spring vs. Fall Election Cycles', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold')
plt.xlabel('Election Cycle', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Total Votes Received', fontsize=12)
plt.xticks(rotation=0)
plt.yticks(range(0, 5))
plt.legend(title='Candidate ID', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left')
plt.grid(axis='y', linestyle='--', alpha=0.6)

# Adding data labels to assist in identifying specific value shifts (e.g., the rise of 1004 in Fall)
for p in ax.patches:
    if p.get_height() > 0:
        ax.annotate(str(int(p.get_height())), 
                    (p.get_x() + p.get_width() / 2., p.get_height()), 
                    ha='center', va='center', 
                    xytext=(0, 7), 
                    textcoords='offset points',
                    fontsize=10)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Load the data
csv_data = """Region,Q1,Q2,Q3,Q4
North America,62397.89,49853.88,32258.41,55213.85
Europe,44511.00,73776.37,70716.35,92668.83
Asia Pacific,53332.90,37175.65,75787.40,84451.03
Latin America,58676.63,76258.03,61084.30,68977.63
Middle East,50652.46,31525.15,35228.73,37042.90
Africa,63184.62,48861.36,62074.24,93991.82"""

df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_data))

# Data Processing for 'Read Beyond' Analysis: Calculate totals and seasonal variance
quarters = ['Q1', 'Q2', 'Q3', 'Q4']
df['Annual Total'] = df[quarters].sum(axis=1)
df_sorted = df.sort_values(by='Annual Total', ascending=True)

# Plotting a stacked horizontal bar chart to analyze market share and quarterly distribution
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 7))

colors = ['#264653', '#2a9d8f', '#e9c46a', '#f4a261']
df_sorted.set_index('Region')[quarters].plot(kind='barh', stacked=True, ax=ax, color=colors, edgecolor='white')

# Adding inference aids: Annual Total labels and Global Sales Percentage
total_global_sales = df['Annual Total'].sum()

for i, (total, region) in enumerate(zip(df_sorted['Annual Total'], df_sorted['Region'])):
    pct = (total / total_global_sales) * 100
    ax.text(total + 5000, i, f'Total: ${total:,.0f} ({pct:.1f}%)', 
            va='center', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold', color='#333333')

# Formatting for professional presentation
ax.set_title('Regional Sales Performance & Seasonal Contribution Analysis', fontsize=16, pad=20, fontweight='bold')
ax.set_xlabel('Revenue (USD)', fontsize=12)
ax.set_ylabel('Region', fontsize=12)
ax.legend(title='Fiscal Quarter', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left')
ax.grid(axis='x', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)
ax.spines['top'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['right'].set_visible(False)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('19store_item.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # Creating data locally for script functionality if file is missing
    data = {
        'Store': ['Cherry St.', 'Strawberry Mall', 'Peach St.', 'Lime Av.', 'Apple Rd.'],
        'Clothing': [8261.68, 7875.87, 4990.23, 4658.42, 3952.00],
        'Equipment': [4810.34, 3126.58, 4923.48, 2955.55, 1858.46],
        'Accessories': [1536.57, 2019.81, 1472.59, 1390.55, 917.90]
    }
    df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Calculate Total Sales to enable 'Read Beyond' insights (comparing relative performance)
df['Total'] = df[['Clothing', 'Equipment', 'Accessories']].sum(axis=1)
df = df.sort_values(by='Total', ascending=False)

# Setup the visualization
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 7))
categories = ['Clothing', 'Equipment', 'Accessories']
colors = ['#2E86AB', '#A23B72', '#F18F01']
bottom = None

# Create a stacked bar chart to analyze category contribution to total store success
for i, category in enumerate(categories):
    plt.bar(df['Store'], df[category], bottom=bottom, label=category, color=colors[i])
    if bottom is None:
        bottom = df[category].copy()
    else:
        bottom += df[category]

# Add a benchmark line (Average Total Sales) to provide context for 'Reading Beyond' the raw numbers
avg_total = df['Total'].mean()
plt.axhline(avg_total, color='black', linestyle='--', linewidth=1, label=f'Avg Total Sales (${avg_total:,.2f})')

# Annotations for deeper analysis
plt.title('Competitive Store Analysis: Revenue Composition vs. Regional Average', fontsize=14, pad=20)
plt.ylabel('Sales Revenue ($)', fontsize=12)
plt.xlabel('Store Location', fontsize=12)
plt.legend(title="Product Categories", loc='upper right')
plt.grid(axis='y', linestyle=':', alpha=0.6)

# Highlight efficiency/anomalies (e.g., Peach St. has equipment sales nearly equal to clothing)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Load the data provided in the prompt
csv_data = """Year,Month,Value
0,2000,Jan,1
1,2000,Feb,2
2,2000,Mar,3
3,2001,Jan,4
4,2001,Feb,5
5,2001,Mar,6
6,2002,Jan,7
7,2002,Feb,8
8,2002,Mar,9"""

# Read CSV into DataFrame
df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_data), index_col=0)

# Reformat the data to compare years side-by-side (Reading Between level)
pivot_df = df.pivot(index='Month', columns='Year', values='Value')

# Ensure the chronological order of months
month_order = ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar']
pivot_df = pivot_df.reindex(month_order)

# Create a chart to compare trends and relationships across years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
for year in pivot_df.columns:
    plt.plot(pivot_df.index, pivot_df[year], marker='o', linewidth=2, label=f'Year {year}')

plt.title('Comparison of Monthly Trends Across Years (2000-2002)', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Month', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Value', fontsize=12)

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from io import StringIO

# Data setup
csv_data = """year,category_a,category_b,category_c
2018,120,80,40
2019,135,90,55
2020,150,95,70
2021,165,110,85
2022,180,130,100
2023,195,150,120"""

df = pd.read_csv(StringIO(csv_data))

# Calculate cumulative totals and relative growth rates for "Read Beyond" analysis
df['total'] = df[['category_a', 'category_b', 'category_c']].sum(axis=1)
df['growth_rate'] = df['total'].pct_change() * 100

# Linear Regression for Projection (Reading Beyond the current data points)
z = np.polyfit(df['year'], df['total'], 1)
p = np.poly1d(z)
future_year = 2024
projection = p(future_year)

# Plotting
fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 7))

# Area chart for composition analysis
colors = ['#2E86C1', '#D35400', '#27AE60']
ax1.stackplot(df['year'], df['category_a'], df['category_b'], df['category_c'], 
              labels=['Category A', 'Category B', 'Category C'], alpha=0.8, colors=colors)

# Plotting the projection line
years_ext = np.append(df['year'].values, future_year)
projection_line = p(years_ext)
ax1.plot(years_ext, projection_line, color='black', linestyle='--', linewidth=2, label='Linear Trend/Projection')

# Annotating the "Read Beyond" inference
ax1.scatter(future_year, projection, color='red', zorder=5)
ax1.annotate(f'Projected 2024 Total: {projection:.0f}\n(Based on 2018-2023 Momentum)', 
             xy=(future_year, projection), xytext=(2020, projection + 50),
             arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black', arrowstyle='->'),
             fontsize=10, fontweight='bold', bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", fc="white", ec="black", alpha=0.8))

# Formatting
ax1.set_title('Compounded Growth Trends (2018-2023) & Predictive Outlook', fontsize=15, pad=20)
ax1.set_xlabel('Year', fontsize=12)
ax1.set_ylabel('Aggregate Value', fontsize=12)
ax1.set_xlim(2018, 2024.5)
ax1.legend(loc='upper left')
ax1.grid(axis='y', linestyle=':', alpha=0.6)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('20iris.csv')

# Set aesthetic style for high-level data interpretation
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")

# Create a JointPlot to satisfy 'Read Beyond' literacy standards.
# This visualization combines raw data points (reading data),
# bivariate correlations (reading between), and Kernel Density Estimations (KDE).
# The KDE contours allow for the inference of species' existence in unobserved
# regions of the feature space and prediction of classification boundaries.
g = sns.jointplot(
    data=df, 
    x="petal_length", 
    y="petal_width", 
    hue="species",
    kind="kde", 
    fill=True, 
    alpha=0.4,
    palette="magma",
    height=8
)

# Overlay the observed data points to ground the statistical inference
g.plot_joint(sns.scatterplot, s=40, alpha=0.8, edgecolor="white", linewidth=0.5)

# Adding predictive labels and title for multivariate analysis
g.set_axis_labels("Petal Length (mm)", "Petal Width (mm)", fontsize=12)
g.fig.suptitle("Morphological Probability Density: Inferring Species Boundaries (Read Beyond)", y=1.02, fontsize=14)

plt.show()

    csv_content = """time_slot_id,day,start_hr,start_min,end_hr,end_min
A,M,8,0,8,50
A,W,8,0,8,50
A,F,8,0,8,50
B,M,9,0,9,50
B,W,9,0,9,50
B,F,9,0,9,50
C,M,11,0,11,50
C,W,11,0,11,50
C,F,11,0,11,50
D,M,13,0,13,50
D,W,13,0,13,50
D,F,13,0,13,50

E,R,10,30,11,45

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Load data
csv_data = """time_slot_id,day,start_hr,start_min,end_hr,end_min
A,M,8,0,8,50
A,W,8,0,8,50
A,F,8,0,8,50
B,M,9,0,9,50
B,W,9,0,9,50
B,F,9,0,9,50
C,M,11,0,11,50
C,W,11,0,11,50
C,F,11,0,11,50
D,M,13,0,13,50
D,W,13,0,13,50
D,F,13,0,13,50
E,T,10,30,11,45
E,R,10,30,11,45
F,T,14,30,15,45
F,R,14,30,15,45
G,M,16,0,16,50
G,W,16,0,16,50
G,F,16,0,16,50
H,W,10,0,12,30"""

df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_data))

# Convert times to decimal hours for plotting
df['start_decimal'] = df['start_hr'] + df['start_min'] / 60
df['end_decimal'] = df['end_hr'] + df['end_min'] / 60
df['duration'] = df['end_decimal'] - df['start_decimal']

# Map days to numeric values for the Y-axis
day_map = {'M': 0, 'T': 1, 'W': 2, 'R': 3, 'F': 4}
df['day_idx'] = df['day'].map(day_map)

# Set up the visualization
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 7))

# Create a color palette for distinct time slots
colors = plt.cm.tab10(range(len(df['time_slot_id'].unique())))
color_map = dict(zip(df['time_slot_id'].unique(), colors))

# Plot each time slot as a horizontal bar (Gantt style)
for i, row in df.iterrows():
    ax.broken_barh([(row['start_decimal'], row['duration'])], 
                   (row['day_idx'] - 0.4, 0.8), 
                   facecolors=color_map[row['time_slot_id']], 
                   edgecolor='black', alpha=0.8)
    # Add text label for the slot ID
    ax.text(row['start_decimal'] + row['duration']/2, row['day_idx'], 
            row['time_slot_id'], ha='center', va='center', fontweight='bold')

# Formatting the chart
ax.set_yticks(range(5))
ax.set_yticklabels(['Monday (M)', 'Tuesday (T)', 'Wednesday (W)', 'Thursday (R)', 'Friday (F)'])
ax.set_xticks(range(8, 19))
ax.set_xticklabels([f"{h}:00" for h in range(8, 19)])
ax.invert_yaxis()
ax.set_xlabel('Time of Day (24h)')
ax.set_title('Weekly Course Schedule Distribution (Reading Beyond: Identifying Overlaps & Density)', fontsize=14)
ax.grid(True, axis='x', linestyle='--', alpha=0.6)

# Highlighting specific observation: Slot H overlap on Wednesday
ax.annotate('Conflict/Overlap: H vs C & E', xy=(11, 2.4), xytext=(12, 3.5),
            arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black', shrink=0.05, width=1, headwidth=5),
            fontsize=10, color='red')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('21heatmapDataOrig.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # Creating a dummy structure if file is missing for demonstration purposes
    import numpy as np
    data = {'A': np.repeat(np.arange(6), 50),
            'B': np.tile(np.arange(50), 6),
            'C': np.random.randint(0, 101, 300)}
    df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Pivot the data to create a matrix format for the heatmap
# Rows = Column A, Columns = Column B, Values = Column C
heatmap_data = df.pivot(index='A', columns='B', values='C')

# Set the figure size
plt.figure(figsize=(16, 6))

# Generate the heatmap
# 'viridis' is a perceptually uniform colormap good for data comparison
sns.heatmap(heatmap_data, cmap='viridis', annot=False, cbar_kws={'label': 'Intensity (C)'})

# Adding descriptive labels for comparative analysis
plt.title('Heatmap Distribution of Values (C) across Categories A and B', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Category B (0-49)', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Category A (0-5)', fontsize=12)

# Display the plot
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Creating the dataset as described in the prompt
csv_data = """cinema_id,name,openning_year,capacity,location
1,Codling,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002010,1100,County Wicklow
2,Carrowleagh,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002012,368,County Cork
3,Dublin Array,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002015,364,County Dublin
4,Glenmore,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002009,305,County Clare
5,Glenough,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002010,325,County Tipperary
6,Gortahile,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002010,208,County Laois
7,Grouse Lodge,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002011,203,County Tipperary
8,Moneypoint,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002011,225,County Clare
9,Mount Callan,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002011,908,County Clare
10,Oriel,1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002013,330,County Louth"""

# Load the data
df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_data))

# Data Cleaning: Extract the actual year from the malformed timestamp string
df['year'] = df['openning_year'].str[-4:].astype(int)

# Analysis: Calculate total capacity and cinema count per location for "Read Beyond" synthesis
location_stats = df.groupby('location').agg({'capacity': 'sum', 'cinema_id': 'count'}).sort_values(by='capacity', ascending=True)

# Visualizing the distribution of infrastructure capacity across regions
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
bars = plt.barh(location_stats.index, location_stats['capacity'], color='skyblue', edgecolor='navy')

# Adding data labels and context
plt.xlabel('Total Seating Capacity')
plt.ylabel('Location (County)')
plt.title('Cinema Infrastructure Capacity by County (2009-2015 Opening Cohort)')
plt.grid(axis='x', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)

# Annotate with the number of cinemas to allow for inference of average cinema size per county
for i, bar in enumerate(bars):
    count = location_stats['cinema_id'].iloc[i]
    plt.text(bar.get_width() + 10, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2, 
             f'({count} Cinema{"s" if count > 1 else ""})', 
             va='center', fontsize=9, color='darkblue')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

from io import StringIO

# Load the data
csv_content = """card_id,customer_id,card_type_code,card_number,date_valid_from,date_valid_to,other_card_details
1,14,Credit,4560596484842,2011-04-17 09:05:28,2018-03-07 17:06:19,5567915676420343
2,9,Credit,4859448397570735,2012-05-22 02:05:41,2018-02-25 15:43:32,4539333582760
3,6,Debit,348237249146948,2014-08-01 14:26:45,2018-03-24 15:29:00,4916210554814
4,15,Credit,4485460762694,2009-11-05 09:26:01,2018-03-19 05:34:08,5296134475180061
5,13,Credit,5122249720639438,2015-12-21 22:07:49,2018-03-22 08:31:28,5388642773088467
6,10,Debit,5102229294602335,2017-01-01 13:34:04,2018-03-11 01:12:33,5513587359761653
7,9,Credit,4716674779726,2016-12-11 03:01:12,2018-03-15 06:27:45,6011771512810699
8,12,Credit,6011225247353230,2016-09-17 13:31:05,2018-03-24 00:38:54,5428692691195935
9,3,Debit,4929590358481,2015-03-27 02:01:12,2018-03-12 02:16:45,5307019264041461
10,10,Debit,4532488235104,2011-06-15 23:10:10,2018-03-17 21:27:32,5571147786750739
11,8,Debit,4707949584519,2013-11-17 02:58:22,2018-03-14 14:00:07,377852690396160
12,3,Debit,4929896676202959,2015-05-09 04:05:26,2018-03-16 16:00:19,4556142375374
13,2,Credit,5484846021884483,2008-08-20 17:59:51,2018-03-20 02:08:02,4916493714393
14,5,Debit,4929384762825,2013-05-23 07:55:36,2018-03-11 06:05:44,4485258248930151
15,2,Debit,345475370003028,2014-07-03 20:19:31,2018-02-28 22:26:31,4716851737494984"""

df = pd.read_csv(StringIO(csv_content))

# Convert to datetime
df['date_valid_from'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date_valid_from'])
df['date_valid_to'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date_valid_to'])

# Calculate card lifespan in years (Read Beyond analysis: inferring policy differences)
df['validity_lifespan_years'] = (df['date_valid_to'] - df['date_valid_from']).dt.days / 365.25

# Visualizing distributions to identify trends in issuance policies
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.set_style("whitegrid")

# Use a boxen plot for a "read beyond" statistical summary of lifespans by card type
sns.boxenplot(x='card_type_code', y='validity_lifespan_years', data=df, palette='viridis')
sns.stripplot(x='card_type_code', y='validity_lifespan_years', data=df, color='black', alpha=0.4)

plt.title('Statistical Distribution of Card Validity Lifespans: Credit vs. Debit', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Card Type', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Years of Validity (From Issue to Expiry)', fontsize=12)

# Adding annotation to guide "reading beyond" the data
plt.annotate('Credit cards show higher variance\nin validity duration than Debit cards.', 
             xy=(0, 7), xytext=(0.5, 8.5),
             arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black', shrink=0.05, width=1, headwidth=5),
             fontsize=10, bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", fc="white", ec="gray", alpha=0.5))

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('2riding_club.csv')

# Preprocessing: Extract the year from the timestamp-like string (the last 4 digits)
df['year'] = df['start_year'].str.extract(r'(\d{4})$').astype(int)

# Sort by year to analyze growth over time
df = df.sort_values('year')

# Calculate the cumulative number of clubs to interpret growth trends (Read Beyond level)
df['cumulative_count'] = range(1, len(df) + 1)

# Create the visualization
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.step(df['year'], df['cumulative_count'], where='post', color='navy', linewidth=2, marker='o', label='Cumulative Clubs')

# Annotating specific data points for inference
for i, txt in enumerate(df['club_name']):
    plt.annotate(txt, (df['year'].iloc[i], df['cumulative_count'].iloc[i]), 
                 textcoords="offset points", xytext=(0,10), ha='center', fontsize=9)

# Setting labels and title
plt.title('Growth Trajectory of Riding Clubs (1998 - 2011)', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Establishment Year', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Total Number of Active Clubs', fontsize=12)
plt.xticks(range(df['year'].min(), df['year'].max() + 1, 2))
plt.yticks(range(1, len(df) + 1))
plt.grid(axis='both', linestyle='--', alpha=0.6)
plt.tight_layout()

# Show plot
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
from datetime import datetime

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('3company_employee.csv')

# Data Transformation for 'Read Beyond' Analysis:
# Calculating Age from bdate to infer relationships between seniority and compensation
df['bdate'] = pd.to_datetime(df['bdate'])
current_year = datetime.now().year
df['age'] = current_year - df['bdate'].dt.year

# Create a visualization to analyze the multi-dimensional relationship 
# between Age, Salary, Department (dno), and Gender (sex).
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 7))

# Scatter plot allows for trend inference and identifying outliers in salary structures
plot = sns.scatterplot(
    data=df, 
    x='age', 
    y='salary', 
    hue='sex', 
    size='dno', 
    style='sex',
    palette='deep', 
    sizes=(100, 400),
    alpha=0.7
)

# Statistical inference: adding a regression line to see the general trend of salary vs age
sns.regplot(data=df, x='age', y='salary', scatter=False, color='gray', label='Salary Trend')

plt.title('Correlation Analysis: Age and Gender Impacts on Salary across Departments', fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel('Estimated Age (Years)', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Annual Salary ($)', fontsize=12)
plt.legend(title='Sex / Dept No', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Data setup
data = """order_item_id,order_id,product_id,product_quantity
1,4,4,6
2,4,10,7
3,15,5,4
4,1,3,9
5,2,14,3
6,13,12,8
7,1,15,3
8,10,4,4
9,14,5,1
10,13,9,2
11,15,7,5
12,4,14,4
13,12,13,1
14,13,14,2
15,13,14,6"""

df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(data))

# Aggregate quantity by product to identify distribution patterns
product_stats = df.groupby('product_id')['product_quantity'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False).reset_index()

# Calculate cumulative percentage for Pareto Analysis (Read Beyond: Identifying the 'Vital Few')
product_stats['cum_percent'] = 100 * product_stats['product_quantity'].cumsum() / product_stats['product_quantity'].sum()

fig, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 7))

# Bar chart for total quantities
bars = ax1.bar(product_stats['product_id'].astype(str), product_stats['product_quantity'], color='steelblue', alpha=0.8, label='Quantity Sold')
ax1.set_xlabel('Product ID', fontsize=12)
ax1.set_ylabel('Total Quantity Sold', fontsize=12)
ax1.set_title('Product Volume Analysis: Identifying Inventory Drivers (Pareto Inference)', fontsize=14)

# Line chart for cumulative percentage
ax2 = ax1.twinx()
ax2.plot(product_stats['product_id'].astype(str), product_stats['cum_percent'], color='red', marker='o', ms=7, label='Cumulative %')
ax2.axhline(80, color='orange', linestyle='--', alpha=0.6)
ax2.set_ylabel('Cumulative Percentage (%)', fontsize=12)
ax2.set_ylim(0, 110)

# Annotations for "Reading Beyond"
ax2.annotate('80% Volume Threshold', xy=(4, 80), xytext=(6, 70),
             arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black', arrowstyle='->'),
             fontsize=10, color='darkorange')

plt.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3)
fig.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('4carsMod.csv')

# Data Prep: Convert 'cyl' to a categorical string to ensure distinct regression lines per group
# This facilitates "reading beyond" by allowing comparison of trends between engine types
df['cyl'] = df['cyl'].astype(int).astype(str)

# Set visual style for complex data interpretation
sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid", palette="Set1")

# Create a regression plot to model the relationship between Horsepower and MPG
# Regression lines represent inferences/predictions beyond individual data points
g = sns.lmplot(
    data=df,
    x="hp",
    y="mpg",
    hue="cyl",
    height=7,
    aspect=1.4,
    scatter_kws={"s": 120, "alpha": 0.6},
    line_kws={"linewidth": 3},
    order=1  # Linear regression for trend prediction
)

# Refine labels and titles to highlight inferential qualities
g.set_axis_labels("Performance (Horsepower)", "Efficiency (Miles Per Gallon)")
g.fig.suptitle(
    "Curcio Literacy Level - Read Beyond: Predictive Modeling of Fuel Efficiency vs. Power", 
    fontsize=16, 
    y=1.05
)

# Display the chart
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
# Assuming '4school_earnings.csv' exists in the local directory
try:
    df = pd.read_csv('4school_earnings.csv')
except FileNotFoundError:
    # Fallback to creating the dataframe from the provided data if file is missing
    import io
    data = """School,Women,Men,Gap
MIT,94,152,58
Stanford,96,151,55
Harvard,112,165,53
U.Penn,92,141,49
Princeton,90,137,47
Chicago,78,118,40
Georgetown,94,131,37
Tufts,76,112,36
Yale,79,114,35
Columbia,86,119,33
Duke,93,124,31
Dartmouth,84,114,30
NYU,67,94,27
Notre Dame,73,100,27
Cornell,80,107,27
Michigan,62,84,22
Brown,72,92,20
Berkeley,71,88,17
Emory,68,82,14
UCLA,64,78,14
SoCal,72,81,9"""
    df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(data))

# Sorting by Men's earnings to help identify patterns and comparisons between schools
df = df.sort_values('Men', ascending=True)

# Create a grouped horizontal bar chart to compare Men vs Women earnings
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 10))
bar_width = 0.35
index = range(len(df))

# Plot bars
plt.barh([i + bar_width/2 for i in index], df['Men'], bar_width, label='Men', color='#4C72B0')
plt.barh([i - bar_width/2 for i in index], df['Women'], bar_width, label='Women', color='#C44E52')

# Annotate the Gap for "Reading Between" comparison
for i, gap in enumerate(df['Gap']):
    plt.text(max(df['Men'].iloc[i], df['Women'].iloc[i]) + 2, i, f'Gap: {gap}', 
             va='center', fontsize=9, color='gray')

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import io

# Load data from the provided CSV structure
csv_data = """category,actual_sales,target_sales
Q1,72,80
Q2,85,80
Q3,90,95
Q4,78,85"""

df = pd.read_csv(io.StringIO(csv_data))

# Calculate variance for "Read Beyond" insights (Performance vs. Target)
df['variance'] = df['actual_sales'] - df['target_sales']
df['color'] = df['variance'].apply(lambda x: '#2ecc71' if x >= 0 else '#e74c3c')

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))

# Create horizontal bars for Actual Sales
bars = ax.barh(df['category'], df['actual_sales'], color=df['color'], alpha=0.7, label='Actual Sales', height=0.5)

# Plot Target Sales as vertical markers (Bullet Chart style)
ax.scatter(df['target_sales'], df['category'], color='black', marker='|', s=1000, linewidth=3, label='Target Sales', zorder=3)

# Add data labels and variance indicators
for i, row in df.iterrows():
    ax.text(row['actual_sales'] + 1, i, f"{row['actual_sales']}", va='center', fontweight='bold')
    ax.text(row['target_sales'], i, f"Target: {row['target_sales']}", va='bottom', ha='center', fontsize=9, color='black')
    
    # Text for Read Beyond: Variance calculation
    prefix = "+" if row['variance'] >= 0 else ""
    ax.text(5, i, f"Gap: {prefix}{row['variance']}", color='white', va='center', fontweight='bold', fontsize=10)

# Formatting
ax.set_title('Quarterly Sales Performance vs. Targets', fontsize=16, pad=20)
ax.set_xlabel('Sales Volume', fontsize=12)
ax.set_xlim(0, 110)
ax.invert_yaxis()  # Q1 at the top
ax.spines['top'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['right'].set_visible(False)
ax.legend(loc='lower right')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
